Well what about just saving the best genome from previous runs? 
Incrementa=
l evolution? I know this introduces potentially unnecessary 
complexity but=
 that genome I see is a perceptron-like structure, it 
can be created with =
NEAT evolution without additive mutations as 
well.. 

Peter

--- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> This brief tutorial is in=
tended to convey a means by which a 
starting 
> genome may be created to c=
orrespond to a desired starting point. 
This 
> usually represents the best=
 "knowledge" to date, a product of user 
> experience or prior evolutionary=
 runs. The ability to start a NEAT 
> evolution with best "knowledge" to da=
te is profoundly more 
effective 
> as a consequence of not "reinventing-th=
e-wheel" each run, and is 
> beneficial to the user as evidenced by useful =
results sooner.
> 
> The example is comprised of (1) input bias node and (8=
) output 
nodes, 
> the values of which are used in the fitness determinati=
on. This 
> parameter estimation problem is utilized to demonstrate a 
mini=
malist 
> approach to this class of problems, but does not represent a 
> l=
imitation of the approach to the more general (x) input and (y) 
> output p=
roblems.
> 
> The procedure is the determination of connection weights betw=
een 
the 
> single bias node to each of the (8) output nodes, such that the=
 
> network activation will result in each of the output's activation 
> co=
rresponding to the normalized version of the desired starting 
> output.
> =

> a) The Start, Max and Min values of each output are normalized to 
> wit=
hin the range of 0 to 1 (or 0.1 & 0.9, etc.).
> b) For the selected bias va=
lue (usually 1.0), solve for the weight 
> value such that fsigmoid of the =
product of bias x weight is equal 
to 
> the normalized value of Start.
> c=
) Perform (a) and (b) above for each output.
> 
> For a bias value of 1.0, =
Normalize_min =3D 0.1 and Normalize_max =3D 
0.9:
> 
> Input	Start	Max	Min	=
Weight
> 1	37.8	50.0	22.5	0.0367272
> 2	2.8	10.0	0.01	-0.149887
> 3	60	500.=
0	0.5	-0.287548
> 4	0.072	1.0	0.001	-0.341533

> =
6	79.44	100.0	0.1	0.207536
> 7	52.33	100.0	0.5	0.0135897
> 8	52.33	100.0	0.=
5	0.0135897
>

>

1
> trait 1 0.1 0 0 0 0 0 0 0

> trait 3 0.3 0 0=
 0 0 0 0 0

ne 3 1 2  0.0367272 0 1 0 1

.287548  0 3 0 1

2 0 1

e 3 1 9  0.0135897 0 2 0 1
> genomeend 1

> For the more general problem =
of (x) inputs and (y) outputs:
> i) # Inputs equals (x) + (1) bias, where a=
ll (x) inputs are left 
> unconnected.
> ii) # Outputs equals (y).
> iii) #=
 weights equals (x), each from the single bias node to each 
of 
> the outp=
ut nodes respectively.
> iv) Procedure for determination of start genome we=
ight values is 
same 
> as above.

zation methodology utilized in

rresponding Experiment
